pr_title: Starts Broker and Server in parallel when using ServiceManager

timeline.message:
Starts Broker and Server in parallel when using ServiceManager

Fixes #5876

timeline.bodyText: intentionally left controller out of here as it seemed there was some reason to. Otherwise, I'd like to put it in :D
timeline.author: codefromthecrypt

replies.bodyText: I dont think there is any reason to not add controller. @fx19880617
replies.author: kishoreg

replies.bodyText:
If it's a new cluster, then controller has to be started first, otherwise broker and server will fail.
Probably we can add a check to decide if the cluster is already there then start controller in parallel as well.
replies.author: xiangfu0

replies.bodyText: hmm so in this case, if you have multiple CLI args, you can be in the wrong order subtly.. maybe they need to be sorted?
replies.author: codefromthecrypt

replies.bodyText: also I don't know how we check if "cluster is already" so if you feed me a command I can...
replies.author: codefromthecrypt

replies.bodyText: If user starts broker/server first for a new cluster, then it will fail in-relevant to your changes.
replies.author: xiangfu0
xiangfu0

replies.bodyText: In the context of SM I don't know what to use as instance_id
replies.author: codefromthecrypt

timeline.bodyText: Add a log before starting the service and another one after the service is started and measure log the time it took to start
timeline.author: kishoreg

replies.bodyText: I presume you mean inside startPinotService as it is a blocking command (then useful for both the parallel and sync paths)
replies.author: codefromthecrypt

replies.bodyText: Agreed, it's good to add logs to measure the startup time.
replies.author: xiangfu0

replies.bodyText: you want to just time each service command here right? this would be different than composite startup time
replies.author: codefromthecrypt

replies.bodyText: Yes, each service. Also log the wall clock time, that will help us understand what’s debug slow starts
replies.author: kishoreg

replies.bodyText:
ok FWIW what I used before was -verbose:gc for similar :P you can see time since startup for each GC event, which are often enough to figure out time like this.
[0.012s][info][gc] Using G1
[0.066s][info][gc] Periodic GC disabled
[0.753s][info][gc] GC(0) Pause Young (Normal) (G1 Evacuation Pause) 12M->2M(256M) 7.433ms
[1.108s][info][gc] GC(1) Pause Young (Normal) (G1 Evacuation Pause) 12M->3M(256M) 9.164ms
[1.511s][info][gc] GC(2) Pause Young (Concurrent Start) (Metadata GC Threshold) 15M->4M(256M) 6.252ms
[1.511s][info][gc] GC(3) Concurrent Cycle
[1.520s][info][gc] GC(3) Pause Remark 4M->4M(256M) 1.834ms
[1.523s][info][gc] GC(3) Pause Cleanup 4M->4M(256M) 0.172ms
[1.525s][info][gc] GC(3) Concurrent Cycle 13.819ms

Ex.
"starting $role at N.NNNs since launch"
"started/error starting $role at N.NNNs since launch"
replies.author: codefromthecrypt

replies.bodyText: Ah nice idea. Go for it!
replies.author: kishoreg

replies.bodyText: Ah nice idea. Go for it!
replies.author: kishoreg

timeline.message: Don't check helix as it spams logs
Ensures any failure results in exit code 1
